[June]166-june was [the portion of [Bosinney]168-bosinney , who was placed between [Irene]186-irene and [[his]233-swithin fiancee]2674-his fiancee]2673-the portion of bosinney , who was placed between irene and his fiancee . On the other side of [June]166-june was [James]173-james with [Mrs. Nicholas]189-nicholas , then [old Jolyon]165-old jolyon with [Mrs. James]173-james , [Nicholas]189-nicholas with [Hatty Chessman]227-hatty chessman , [Soames]232-soames with [Mrs. Small]177-soames , completing , the circle to [Swithin]233-swithin again . Family dinners of [the Forsytes]164-soames observe certain traditions . There are , for instance , no hors d'oeuvre . The reason for this is unknown . Theory among [the younger members]2675-the younger members traces it to the disgraceful price of oysters ; it is more probably due to a desire to come to the point , to a good practical sense deciding at once that hors d'oeuvre are but poor things . [The Jameses]196-the jameses alone , unable to withstand a custom almost universal in [Park Lane]14-park lane , are now and then unfaithful . A silent , almost morose , inattention to [each other]2556-each other succeeds to the subsidence into [their]2556-each other seats , lasting till well into the first entree , but interspersed with remarks such as , "[234-mr. boswainey] [Tom]182-tommy 's bad again ; [I]0-i ca n't tell what 's the matter with [him]182-tommy ! " "[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [Ann]169-aunt ann does n't come down in the mornings ? " - "[169-aunt ann] What 's the name of [[your]0-i doctor]767-your doctor , [Fanny]226-nicholas ? " "[226-nicholas] [Stubbs]235-stubbs ? " "[182-tommy] [He]182-tommy 's a quack ! " - "[182-tommy] [Winifred]187-dartie ? [She]768-she 's got [too many children]769-too many children . Four , is n't it ? [She]768-she 's as thin as a lath ! " - "[768-she] What d'you give for this sherry , [Swithin]233-swithin ? Too dry for [me]0-i ! " With the second glass of champagne , a kind of hum makes itself heard , which , when divested of casual accessories and resolved into its primal element , is found to be [James]173-james telling a story , and this goes on for a long time , encroaching sometimes even upon what must universally be recognised as the crowning point of a Forsyte feast - ' the saddle of mutton . ' [No Forsyte]232-soames has given a dinner without providing a saddle of mutton . There is something in its succulent solidity which makes it suitable to [people]600-people ' of a certain position . ' It is nourishing and tasty ; the sort of thing [a man]515-a man remembers eating . It has a past and a future , like a deposit paid into a bank ; and it is something that can be argued about . [Each branch of [the family]450-the family]2679-each branch of the family tenaciously held to [a particular locality]2681-a particular locality - [old Jolyon]165-old jolyon swearing by [Dartmoor]44-dartmoor , [James]173-james by [Welsh]45-welsh , [Swithin]233-swithin by [Southdown]46-southdown , [Nicholas]226-nicholas maintaining that [people]600-people might sneer , but there was nothing like [New Zealand]47-new zealand ! As for [Roger]317-roger , [the ' original ' of [the brothers]708-the brothers]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers , [he]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers had been obliged to invent [a locality of [his]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers own]2685-a locality of his own , and with an ingenuity worthy of [a man who had devised a new profession for [[his]2686-a man who had devised a new profession for his sons sons]2687-his sons]2686-a man who had devised a new profession for his sons , [he]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers had discovered [a shop where [they]2687-his sons sold [German]236-german]2688-a shop where they sold german ; on being remonstrated with , [he]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers had proved [his]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers point by producing [a butcher]2689-a butcher 's bill , which showed that [he]2683-the ' original ' of the brothers paid more than [any of [the others]2691-the others]2690-any of the others . It was on this occasion that [old Jolyon]165-old jolyon , turning to [June]166-june , had said in one of [his]165-old jolyon bursts of philosophy : "[770-you] [You]770-you may depend upon it , [they]771-they 're [a cranky lot]772-a cranky lot , [the Forsytes]164-soames - and [you]770-you 'll find it out , as [you]770-you grow older ! " [Timothy]170-timothy alone held apart , for though [he]170-timothy ate saddle of mutton heartily , [he]170-timothy was , [he]170-timothy said , afraid of it . To anyone interested psychologically in [Forsytes]164-soames , this great saddle - of - mutton trait is of prime importance ; not only does it illustrate [their]771-they tenacity , both collectively and as [individuals]2692-individuals , but it marks [them]771-they as belonging in fibre and instincts to that great class which believes in nourishment and flavour , and yields to no sentimental craving for beauty . [Younger members of the family]2693-younger members of the family indeed would have done without a joint altogether , preferring guinea - fowl , or lobster salad - something which appealed to the imagination , and had less nourishment - but these were [females]2694-females ; or , if not , had been corrupted by [[their]2693-younger members of the family wives]666-their wives , or by [[mothers]2696-mothers , who having been forced to eat saddle of mutton throughout [their]2696-mothers married lives , had passed a secret hostility towards it into the fibre of [[their]2696-mothers sons]2698-their sons]2697-mothers , who having been forced to eat saddle of mutton throughout their married lives , had passed a secret hostility towards it into the fibre of their sons . The great saddle - of - mutton controversy at an end , a Tewkesbury ham commenced , together with the least touch of [West Indian]48-west indian - [Swithin]233-swithin was so long over this course that [he]233-swithin caused a block in the progress of the dinner . To devote [himself]233-swithin to it with better heart , [he]233-swithin paused in [his]233-swithin conversation . From [his]233-swithin seat by [Mrs. Septimus Small Soames]177-soames was watching . [He]233-swithin had a reason of [his]233-swithin own connected with [a pet building scheme]2699-a pet building scheme , for observing [Bosinney]168-bosinney . [The architect]2700-the architect might do for [his]2700-the architect purpose ; [he]2700-the architect looked clever , as [he]2700-the architect sat leaning back in [his]2700-the architect chair , moodily making little ramparts with bread - crumbs . [Soames]177-soames noted [his]233-swithin dress clothes to be well cut , but too small , as though made many years ago . [He]233-swithin saw [him]233-swithin turn to [Irene]186-irene and say something and [her]186-irene face sparkle as [he]233-swithin often saw it sparkle at [other people]2701-other people - never at [himself]233-swithin . [He]233-swithin tried to catch what [they]2702-they were saying , but [Aunt Juley]237-aunt juley was speaking . Had n't that always seemed very extraordinary to [Soames]177-soames ? Only last Sunday dear [Mr. Scole]238-mr. scole , had been so witty in [his]773-he sermon , so sarcastic , "[773-he] For what , " [he]773-he had said , ' shall it profit [a man]515-a man if [he]515-a man gain [his]515-a man own soul , but lose all [his]515-a man property ? "[773-he] That , [he]773-he had said , was the motto of [the middle - class]774-the middle - class ; now , what had [he]773-he meant by that ? Of course , it might be what [middle - class people]775-middle - class people believed - [she]776-her did n't know ; what did [Soames]177-soames think ? [He]773-he answered abstractedly : " How should [I]773-he know ? [Scoles]182-tommy is [a humbug]2704-a humbug , though , is n't [he]182-tommy ? "[773-he] [For Bosinney]168-bosinney was looking round the table , as if pointing out the peculiarities of [the guests]777-the guests , and [Soames]177-soames wondered what [he]773-he was saying . By [her]776-her smile [Irene]186-irene was evidently agreeing with [his]773-he remarks . [She]186-irene seemed always to agree with [other people]2701-other people . [Her]186-irene eyes were turned on [himself]773-he ; [Soames]177-soames dropped [his]773-he glance at once . The smile had died off [her]776-her lips . [A humbug]2704-a humbug ? But what did [Soames]177-soames mean ? If [Mr. Scoles]239-mr. scoles was [a humbug]2704-a humbug , [a clergyman]781-a clergyman - then [anybody]2303-anybody might be - it was frightful ! " Well , and so [they]783-all ye who enter here are ! "[177-soames] said [Soames]177-soames . During [Aunt Juley]237-aunt juley 's momentary and horrified silence [he]773-he caught some words of [Irene]186-irene 's that sounded like : ' Abandon hope , [all [ye]784-ye who enter [here]735-here]783-all ye who enter here ! ' But [Swithin]233-swithin had finished [his]233-swithin ham . " Where do [you]186-irene go for [your]186-irene mushrooms ? "[233-swithin] [he]233-swithin was saying to [Irene]186-irene in a voice like [a courtier]786-a courtier 's ; " [you]186-irene ought to go to [Smileybob]240-smileybob 's - [he]233-swithin 'll give 'em [you]186-irene fresh . "[233-swithin] [Irene]186-irene turned to answer [him]233-swithin , and [Soames]177-soames saw [Bosinney]168-bosinney watching [her]186-irene and smiling to [himself]168-bosinney . A curious smile [the fellow]2355-the fellow had . A half - simple arrangement , like [a child who smiles when [he]788-a child who smiles when he is pleased is pleased]788-a child who smiles when he is pleased . As for [George]183-george 's nickname - ' [The Buccaneer]789-the buccaneer ' - [he]233-swithin did not think much of that . And , seeing [Bosinney]168-bosinney turn to [June]166-june , [Soames]177-soames smiled too , but sardonically - [he]233-swithin did not like [June]166-june , who was not looking too pleased . This was not surprising , for [she]166-june had just held the following conversation with [James]173-james : " [I]166-june stayed on [the river]2706-the river on [my]166-june way [home]436-home , [Uncle James]241-james , and saw a beautiful site for [a house]689-a house . "[166-june] [James]241-james , [a slow and thorough eater]790-a slow and thorough eater , stopped the process of mastication . " Eh ? "[241-james] [he]241-james said . " Now , where was that ? "[241-james] " Close to [Pangbourne]49-pangbourne . "[241-james] [James]241-james placed a piece of ham in [his]241-james mouth , and [June]166-june waited . " [I]241-james suppose [you]166-june would n't know whether [the land]2525-the land about there was freehold ? "[241-james] [he]241-james asked at last . " [You]166-june would n't know anything about the price of land about there ? "[241-james] " Yes , "[166-june] said [June]166-june ; " [I]166-june made inquiries . "[166-june] [Her]166-june little resolute face under its copper crown was suspiciously eager and aglow . [James]241-james regarded [her]166-june with the air of [an inquisitor]791-an inquisitor . " What ? [You]166-june 're not thinking of buying land ! "[241-james] [he]241-james ejaculated , dropping [his]241-james fork . [June]166-june was greatly encouraged by [his]241-james interest . It had long been [her]166-june pet plan that [[her]166-june uncles]792-her uncles should benefit [themselves]792-her uncles and [Bosinney]168-bosinney by building [country - houses]793-country - houses . " Of course not , "[166-june] [she]166-june said . " [I]166-june thought it would be such a splendid place for - [you]241-james or - [someone]2710-someone to build [a country - house]2711-a country - house ! "[166-june] [James]241-james looked at [her]166-june sideways , and placed a second piece of ham in [his]241-james mouth .... " [Land]50-land ought to be very dear about there , "[241-james] [he]241-james said . What [June]166-june had taken for personal interest was only the impersonal excitement of [every Forsyte who hears of something eligible in danger of passing into other hands]794-every forsyte who hears of something eligible in danger of passing into other hands . But [she]166-june refused to see the disappearance of [her]166-june chance , and continued to press [her]166-june point . " [You]241-james ought to go into [the country]2374-the country , [Uncle James]241-james . [I]166-june wish [I]166-june had a lot of money , [I]166-june would n't live another day in [London]2-london . "[166-june] [James]241-james was stirred to the depths of [his]241-james long thin figure ; [he]241-james had no idea [[his]241-james niece]795-his niece held such downright views . " Why do n't [you]241-james go into [the country]2374-the country ? "[166-june] repeated [June]166-june ; " it would do [you]241-james a lot of good . "[166-june] " Why ? "[241-james] began [James]241-james in a fluster . " Buying land - what good d'you suppose [I]241-james can do buying land , building [houses]2315-houses ? - [I]241-james could n't get four per cent . for [my]241-james money ! "[241-james] " What does that matter ? [You]241-james 'd get fresh air . "[166-june] " Fresh air ! "[241-james] exclaimed [James]241-james ; " what should [I]241-james do with fresh air , "[241-james] " [I]166-june should have thought [anybody]2303-anybody liked to have fresh air , "[166-june] said [June]166-june scornfully . [James]241-james wiped [his]241-james napkin all over [his]241-james mouth . " [You]166-june do n't know the value of money , "[241-james] [he]241-james said , avoiding [her]166-june eye . " No ! and [I]241-james hope [I]241-james never shall ! "[241-james] and , biting [her]166-june lip with inexpressible mortification , [poor June]166-june was silent . Why were [[her]166-june own relations]796-her own relations so rich , and [Phil]168-bosinney never knew where the money was coming from for to - morrow 's tobacco . Why could n't [they]796-her own relations do something for [him]168-bosinney ? But [they]796-her own relations were so selfish . Why could n't [they]796-her own relations build [country - houses]793-country - houses ? [She]166-june had all that naive dogmatism which is so pathetic , and sometimes achieves such great results . [Bosinney]168-bosinney , to whom [she]166-june turned in [her]166-june discomfiture , was talking to [Irene]186-irene , and a chill fell on [June]166-june 's spirit . [Her]166-june eyes grew steady with anger , like [old Jolyon]165-old jolyon 's when [his]165-old jolyon will was crossed . [James]241-james , too , was much disturbed . [He]241-james felt as though [someone]2710-someone had threatened [his]241-james right to invest [his]241-james money at five per cent . [Jolyon]165-old jolyon had spoiled [her]166-june . [None of [[his]241-james girls]800-his girls]799-none of his girls would have said such a thing . [James]241-james had always been exceedingly liberal to [[his]241-james children]801-his children , and the consciousness of this made [him]241-james feel it all the more deeply . [He]241-james trifled moodily with [his]241-james strawberries , then , deluging them with cream , [he]241-james ate them quickly ; they , at all events , should not escape [him]241-james . No wonder [he]241-james was upset . Engaged for fifty - four years [he]241-james had been admitted [a solicitor]802-a solicitor on the earliest day sanctioned by the law in arranging mortgages , preserving investments at a dead level of high and safe interest , conducting negotiations on the principle of securing the utmost possible out of other people compatible with safety to [[his]241-james clients]803-his clients and [himself]241-james , in calculations as to the exact pecuniary possibilities of all the relations of life , [he]241-james had come at last to think purely in terms of money . Money was now [his]241-james light , [his]241-james medium for seeing , that without which [he]241-james was really unable to see , really not cognisant of phenomena ; and to have this thing , " [I]241-james hope [I]241-james shall never know the value of money ! "[241-james] said to [his]241-james face , saddened and exasperated [him]241-james . [He]241-james knew it to be nonsense , or it would have frightened [him]241-james . What was [the world]2286-the world coming to ! Suddenly recollecting the story of [young Jolyon]165-old jolyon , however , [he]241-james felt a little comforted , for what could [you]805-you expect with [a father]806-a father like that ! This turned [his]241-james thoughts into a channel still less pleasant . What was all this talk about [Soames]177-soames and [Irene]186-irene ? As in [all self - respecting families]807-all self - respecting families , an emporium had been established where family secrets were bartered , and family stock priced . It was known on [Forsyte]165-old jolyon ' Change that [Irene]186-irene regretted [her]186-irene marriage . [Her]186-irene regret was disapproved of . [She]186-irene ought to have known [her]186-irene own mind ; [no dependable woman]808-no dependable woman made these mistakes . [James]241-james reflected sourly that [they]809-they had [a nice house]810-a nice house rather small in an excellent position , [no children]2293-no children , and no money troubles . [Soames]177-soames was reserved about [his]165-old jolyon affairs , but [he]165-old jolyon must be getting [a very warm man]812-a very warm man . [He]165-old jolyon had a capital income from the business - for [Soames]177-soames , like [[his]165-old jolyon father]559-his father , was a member of [that well - known firm of solicitors]814-that well - known firm of solicitors , [Forsyte]241-james , [Bustard]242-bustard and [Forsyte]241-james - and had always been very careful . [He]165-old jolyon had done quite unusually well with some mortgages [he]165-old jolyon had taken up , too - a little timely foreclosure - most lucky hits ! There was no reason why [Irene]186-irene should not be happy , yet [they]809-they said [she]186-irene 'd been asking for [a separate room]563-a separate room . [He]165-old jolyon knew where that ended . It was n't as if [Soames]177-soames drank . [James]241-james looked at [[his]241-james daughter - in - law]816-his daughter - in - law . That unseen glance of [his]241-james was cold and dubious . Appeal and fear were in it , and a sense of personal grievance . Why should [he]241-james be worried like this ? It was very likely all nonsense ; [women]817-women were funny things ! [They]817-women exaggerated so , [you]818-you did n't know what to believe ; and then , [nobody]2292-nobody told [him]241-james anything , [he]241-james had to find out everything for [himself]241-james . Again [he]241-james looked furtively at [Irene]186-irene , and across from [her]186-irene to [Soames]177-soames . [The latter]2450-the latter , listening to [Aunt Juley]237-aunt juley , was looking up , under [his]241-james brows in the direction of [Bosinney]168-bosinney . ' [He]821-he 's fond of [her]186-irene , [I]0-i know , ' thought [James]241-james . ' Look at the way [he]821-he 's always giving [her]186-irene things . ' And the extraordinary unreasonableness of [her]186-irene disaffection struck [him]241-james with increased force . It was a pity , too , [she]186-irene was a taking little thing , and [he]241-james , [James]241-james , would be really quite fond of [her]186-irene if [she]186-irene 'd only let [him]241-james . [She]186-irene had taken up lately with [June]166-june ; that was doing [her]186-irene no good , that was certainly doing [her]186-irene no good . [She]186-irene was getting to have opinions of [her]186-irene own . [He]241-james did n't know what [she]186-irene wanted with anything of the sort . [She]822-she 'd [a good home]823-a good home , and everything [she]186-irene could wish for . [He]241-james felt that [[her]186-irene friends]824-her friends ought to be chosen for [her]186-irene . To go on like this was dangerous . [June]166-june , indeed , with [her]166-june habit of championing [the unfortunate]825-the unfortunate , had dragged from [Irene]186-irene a confession , and , in return , had preached the necessity of facing the evil , by separation , if need be . But in the face of these exhortations , [Irene]186-irene had kept a brooding silence , as though [she]186-irene found terrible the thought of this struggle carried through in cold blood . [He]241-james would never give [her]186-irene up , [she]186-irene had said to [June]166-june . " Who cares ? "[166-june] [June]166-june cried ; " let [him]241-james do what [he]241-james likes - [you]241-james 've only to stick to it ! "[166-june] And [she]186-irene had not scrupled to say something of this sort at [Timothy]170-timothy 's ; [James]241-james , when [he]241-james heard of it , had felt a natural indignation and horror . What if [Irene]186-irene were to take it into [her]186-irene head to - [he]241-james could hardly frame the thought - to leave [Soames]177-soames ? But [he]241-james felt this thought so unbearable that [he]241-james at once put it away ; the shady visions it conjured up , the sound of family tongues buzzing in [his]241-james ears , the horror of the conspicuous happening so close to [him]241-james , to [one of [[his]241-james own children]827-his own children]826-one of his own children ! Luckily , [she]186-irene had no money - a beggarly fifty pound a year ! And [he]241-james thought of the deceased [Heron]201-heron , who had had nothing to leave [her]186-irene , with contempt . Brooding over [his]241-james glass , [his]241-james long legs twisted under the table , [he]241-james quite omitted to rise when [the ladies]828-the ladies left [the room]488-the room . [He]241-james would have to speak to [Soames]177-soames - would have to put [him]241-james on [his]241-james guard ; [they]830-they could not go on like this , now that such a contingency had occurred to [him]241-james . And [he]241-james noticed with sour disfavour that [June]166-june had left [her]166-june wine - glasses full of wine . ' That little , thing 's at the bottom of it all , ' [he]241-james mused ; ' [Irene'd]243-irene'd never have thought of it [herself]243-irene'd . ' [James]241-james was [a man of imagination]831-a man of imagination . The voice of [Swithin]233-swithin roused [him]241-james from [his]241-james reverie . " [I]241-james gave four hundred pounds for it , "[241-james] [he]241-james was saying . " Of course it 's a regular work of art . "[241-james] " Four hundred ! H'm ! that 's a lot of money ! "[226-nicholas] chimed in [Nicholas]226-nicholas . The object alluded to was an elaborate group of statuary in Italian marble , which , placed upon a lofty stand also of marble , diffused an atmosphere of culture throughout [the room]488-the room . [The subsidiary figures , of which there were six , female , nude , and of highly ornate workmanship]833-the subsidiary figures , of which there were six , female , nude , and of highly ornate workmanship , were all pointing towards [the central figure]834-the central figure , also nude , and female , who was pointing at [herself]166-june ; and all this gave [the observer]682-the observer a very pleasant sense of [her]166-june extreme value . [Aunt Juley]237-aunt juley , nearly opposite , had had the greatest difficulty in not looking at it all the evening . [Old Jolyon]163-old jolyon spoke ; it was [he]163-old jolyon who had started the discussion . " Four hundred fiddlesticks ! Do n't tell [me]163-old jolyon [you]233-swithin gave four hundred for that ? "[163-old jolyon] Between the points of [his]241-james collar [Swithin]233-swithin 's chin made the second painful oscillatory movement of the evening . " Four - hundred - pounds , of English money ; not a farthing less . [I]163-old jolyon do n't regret it . It 's not common English - it 's genuine modern Italian ! "[163-old jolyon] [Soames]177-soames raised the corner of [his]241-james lip in a smile , and looked across at [Bosinney]168-bosinney . "[226-nicholas] chimed in [Nicholas]226-nicholas suddenly , " [poor , seedy - lookin ' chaps]2717-poor , seedy - lookin ' chaps , [these artists]2718-these artists ; it 's a wonder to [me]226-nicholas how [they]2718-these artists live . "[226-nicholas] [James]241-james shook [his]241-james head . " Ah ! "[233-swithin] [he]233-swithin said , " [I]233-swithin do n't know how [they]2718-these artists live ! "[233-swithin] [Old Jolyon]163-old jolyon had risen , and , cigar in mouth , went to inspect [the group]838-the group at close quarters . " Would n't have given two for it ! "[233-swithin] [he]233-swithin pronounced at last . ' [I]0-i wonder what [he]168-bosinney thinks of it ? ' thought [Soames]177-soames , who knew well enough that [this group]842-this group was hopelessly vieux jeu ; hopelessly of [the last generation]843-the last generation . There was no longer any sale at [Jobson]191-jobson 's for such works of art . [Swithin]233-swithin 's answer came at last . " [You]163-old jolyon never knew anything about a statue . [You]163-old jolyon 've got [your]163-old jolyon pictures , and that 's all ! "[233-swithin] [Old Jolyon]163-old jolyon walked back to [his]163-old jolyon seat , puffing [his]163-old jolyon cigar . It was not likely that [he]163-old jolyon was going to be drawn into an argument with [an obstinate beggar like [Swithin]233-swithin , pig - headed as a mule , who had never known a statue from a - -straw hat]844-an obstinate beggar like swithin , pig - headed as a mule , who had never known a statue from a - -straw hat . " [Stucco]245-stucco ! "[163-old jolyon] was all [he]163-old jolyon said . It had long been physically impossible for [Swithin]233-swithin to start ; [his]233-swithin fist came down on the table . " [Stucco]245-stucco ! [I]233-swithin should like to see anything [you]163-old jolyon 've got in [[your]163-old jolyon house]2720-your house half as good ! "[233-swithin] And behind [his]233-swithin speech seemed to sound again that rumbling violence of primitive generations . It was [James]241-james who saved the situation . " Now , what do [you]168-bosinney say , [Mr. Bosinney]168-bosinney ? [You]168-bosinney 're [an architect]518-an architect ; [you]168-bosinney ought to know all about statues and things ! "[241-james] Every eye was turned upon [Bosinney]168-bosinney ; [all]592-all waited with a strange , suspicious look for [his]168-bosinney answer . [And Soames]177-soames , speaking for the first time , asked : " Yes , [Bosinney]168-bosinney , what do [you]168-bosinney say ? "[177-soames] [Bosinney]168-bosinney replied coolly : " The work is a remarkable one . "[168-bosinney] [His]233-swithin words were addressed to [Swithin]233-swithin , [his]233-swithin eyes smiled slyly at [old Jolyon]163-old jolyon ; only [Soames]177-soames remained unsatisfied . " Remarkable for what ? "[177-soames] " For its naivete "[233-swithin] The answer was followed by an impressive silence ; [Swithin]233-swithin alone was not sure whether a compliment was intended . CHAPTER IV - PROJECTION OF [THE HOUSE Soames Forsyte]171-soames walked out of [his]171-soames green - painted front door three days after the dinner at [Swithin 's]172-swithin , and looking back from across [the Square]846-the square , confirmed [his]171-soames impression that [the house]2326-the house wanted painting . [He]171-soames had left [[his]171-soames wife]558-his wife sitting on the sofa in [the drawing - room]849-the drawing - room , [her]558-his wife hands crossed in [her]558-his wife lap , manifestly waiting for [him]171-soames to go out . This was not unusual . It happened , in fact , every day . [He]171-soames could not understand what [she]558-his wife found wrong with [him]171-soames . It was not as if [he]171-soames drank ! Did [he]171-soames run into debt , or gamble , or swear ; was [he]171-soames violent ; were [[his]171-soames friends]850-his friends rackety ; did [he]171-soames stay out at night ? On the contrary . The profound , subdued aversion which [he]171-soames felt in [[his]171-soames wife]558-his wife was a mystery to [him]171-soames , and a source of the most terrible irritation . That [she]558-his wife had made a mistake , and did not love [him]171-soames , had tried to love [him]171-soames and could not love [him]171-soames , was obviously no reason . [He]171-soames that could imagine so outlandish a cause for [[his]171-soames wife]558-his wife 's not getting on with [him]171-soames was certainly no [Forsyte]171-soames . [Soames]171-soames was forced , therefore , to set the blame entirely down to [[his]171-soames wife]558-his wife . [He]171-soames had never met [a woman so capable of inspiring affection]854-a woman so capable of inspiring affection . [They]855-they could not go anywhere without [his]171-soames seeing how [all the men]856-all the men were attracted by [her]558-his wife ; [their]856-all the men looks , manners , voices , betrayed it ; [her]558-his wife behaviour under this attention had been beyond reproach . That [she]558-his wife was [one of those women - not too common in [the Anglo - Saxon race]858-the anglo - saxon race - born to be loved and to love , who when not loving are not living , had certainly never even occurred to [him]171-soames]857-one of those women - not too common in the anglo - saxon race - born to be loved and to love , who when not loving are not living , had certainly never even occurred to him . [Her]558-his wife power of attraction , [he]171-soames regarded as part of [her]558-his wife value as [his]171-soames property ; but it made [him]171-soames , indeed , suspect that [she]558-his wife could give as well as receive ; and [she]558-his wife gave [him]171-soames nothing ! ' Then why did [she]558-his wife marry [me]0-i ? ' was [his]171-soames continual thought . [He]171-soames had , forgotten [his]171-soames courtship ; that year and a half when [he]171-soames had besieged and lain in wait for [her]558-his wife , devising schemes for [her]558-his wife entertainment , giving [her]558-his wife presents , proposing to [her]558-his wife periodically , and keeping [[her]558-his wife other admirers]859-her other admirers away with [his]171-soames perpetual presence . [He]171-soames had forgotten the day when , adroitly taking advantage of an acute phase of [her]558-his wife dislike to [[her]558-his wife home surroundings]860-her home surroundings , [he]171-soames crowned [his]171-soames labours with success . If [he]171-soames remembered anything , it was the dainty capriciousness with which [the gold - haired , dark - eyed girl]861-the gold - haired , dark - eyed girl had treated [him]171-soames . [He]171-soames certainly did not remember the look on [her]558-his wife face - strange , passive , appealing - when suddenly one day [she]558-his wife had yielded , and said that [she]558-his wife would marry [him]171-soames . It had been one of those real devoted wooings which books and [people]600-people praise , when [the lover]863-the lover is at length rewarded for hammering the iron till it is malleable , and all must be happy ever after as the wedding bells . [Soames]171-soames walked eastwards , mousing doggedly along on the shady side . [The house]2326-the house wanted doing , up , unless [he]171-soames decided to move into [the country]2374-the country , and build . For the hundredth time that month [he]171-soames turned over this problem . There was no use in rushing into things ! [He]171-soames was very comfortably off , with an increasing income getting on for three thousand a year ; but [his]171-soames invested capital was not perhaps so large as [[his]171-soames father]559-his father believed - [James]241-james had a tendency to expect that [[his]241-james children]801-his children should be better off than [they]801-his children were . ' [I]0-i can manage eight thousand easily enough , ' [he]171-soames thought , ' without calling in either [Robertson]247-robertson 's or [Nicholl]248-the nicholl 's . ' [He]171-soames had stopped to look in at [a picture shop]868-a picture shop , for [Soames]171-soames was [an ' amateur ' of pictures]869-an ' amateur ' of pictures , and had [a little - room in [No . 62]871-no . 62 , [Montpellier Square]8-montpellier square , full of canvases , stacked against the wall , which [he]171-soames had no room to hang]870-a little - room in no . 62 , montpellier square , full of canvases , stacked against the wall , which he had no room to hang . [He]171-soames brought [them]872-them [home]436-home with [him]171-soames on [his]171-soames way back from [the City]2392-the city , generally after dark , and would enter [this room]2350-this room on Sunday afternoons , to spend hours turning the pictures to the light , examining the marks on [their]872-them backs , and occasionally making notes . [They]872-them were nearly all landscapes with figures in the foreground , a sign of some mysterious revolt against [London]2-london , [its tall houses]876-its tall houses , [its]2-london interminable streets , where [his]171-soames life and the lives of [his]171-soames breed and class were passed . Every now and then [he]171-soames would take one or two pictures away with [him]171-soames in [a cab]2536-a cab , and stop at [Jobson 's]191-jobson on [his]171-soames way into [the City]2392-the city . [He]171-soames rarely showed them to [anyone]879-anyone ; [Irene]186-irene , whose opinion [he]171-soames secretly respected and perhaps for that reason never solicited , had only been into [the room]488-the room on rare occasions , in discharge of some wifely duty . [She]186-irene was not asked to look at the pictures , and [she]186-irene never did . To [Soames]171-soames this was another grievance . [He]171-soames hated that pride of [hers]186-irene , and secretly dreaded it . In the plate - glass window of [the picture shop]881-the picture shop [his]171-soames image stood and looked at [him]171-soames . [His]171-soames sleek hair under the brim of the tall hat had a sheen like the hat itself ; [his]171-soames cheeks , pale and flat , the line of [his]171-soames clean - shaven lips , [his]171-soames firm chin with its greyish shaven tinge , and the buttoned strictness of [his]171-soames black cut - away coat , conveyed an appearance of reserve and secrecy , of imperturbable , enforced composure ; but [his]171-soames eyes , cold , - grey , strained - looking , with a line in the brow between them , examined [him]171-soames wistfully , as if [they]882-they knew of a secret weakness . [He]171-soames noted the subjects of the pictures , the names of [the painters]883-the painters , made a calculation of [their]883-the painters values , but without the satisfaction [he]171-soames usually derived from this inward appraisement , and walked on . [No . 62]871-no . 62 would do well enough for another year , if [he]171-soames decided to build ! The times were good for building , money had not been so dear for years ; and [the site [he]171-soames had seen at [Robin Hill]53-robin hill]885-the site he had seen at robin hill , when [he]171-soames had gone down [there]454-there in the spring to inspect [the Nicholl]248-the nicholl mortgage - what could be better ! Within twelve miles of [Hyde Park Corner]55-hyde park corner , the value of the land certain to go up , would always fetch more than [he]171-soames gave for it ; so that [a house]689-a house , if built in really good style , was a first - class investment . The notion of being [the one member of [[his]171-soames family]2527-his family with [a country house]890-a country house]888-the one member of his family with a country house weighed but little with [him]171-soames ; for to [a true Forsyte]891-a true forsyte , sentiment , even the sentiment of social position , was a luxury only to be indulged in after [his]171-soames appetite for more material pleasure had been satisfied . To get [Irene]186-irene out of [London]2-london , away from opportunities of going about and seeing [people]600-people , away from [[her]186-irene friends]824-her friends and [those who put ideas into [her]186-irene head]894-those who put ideas into her head ! That was the thing ! [She]186-irene was too thick with [June]166-june ! [June]166-june disliked [him]171-soames . [He]171-soames returned the sentiment . [They]895-they were of the same blood . It would be everything to get [Irene]186-irene out of [town]656-town . [The house]2326-the house would please [her]186-irene [she]186-irene would enjoy messing about with the decoration , [she]186-irene was very artistic ! [The house]2326-the house must be in good style , something that would always be certain to command a price , something unique , like [that last house of [Parkes]249-parkes , which had [a tower]900-a tower]899-that last house of parkes , which had a tower ; but [Parkes]249-parkes had [himself]249-parkes said that [[his]249-parkes architect]901-his architect was ruinous . [You]902-you never knew where [you]902-you were with [those fellows]903-those fellows ; if [they]903-those fellows had a name [they]903-those fellows ran [you]902-you into no end of expense and were conceited into the bargain . And [a common architect]904-a common architect was no good - the memory of [[Parkes]249-parkes ' tower]905-parkes ' tower precluded the employment of [a common architect]904-a common architect : This was why [he]249-parkes had thought of [Bosinney]168-bosinney . Since the dinner at [Swithin]233-swithin 's [he]249-parkes had made enquiries , the result of which had been meagre , but encouraging : " One of [the new school]2722-the new school . "[249-parkes] " Clever ? "[249-parkes] " As clever as [you]168-bosinney like - a bit - a bit up in the air ! "[249-parkes] [He]249-parkes had not been able to discover what [houses]2315-houses [Bosinney]168-bosinney had built , nor what [his]249-parkes charges were . The impression [he]249-parkes gathered was that [he]249-parkes would be able to make [his]249-parkes own terms . The more [he]249-parkes reflected on the idea , the more [he]249-parkes liked it . It would be keeping the thing in [the family]450-the family , with [Forsytes]164-soames almost an instinct ; and [he]249-parkes would be able to get ' favoured - nation , ' if not nominal terms - only fair , considering the chance to [Bosinney]168-bosinney of displaying [his]168-bosinney talents , for [this house]752-this house must be [no common edifice]910-no common edifice . [Soames]164-soames reflected complacently on the work it would be sure to bring [the young man]2291-the young man ; for , like [every Forsyte]912-every forsyte , [he]249-parkes could be [a thorough optimist]913-a thorough optimist when there was anything to be had out of it . [[Bosinney]168-bosinney 's office]914-bosinney 's office was in [Sloane Street]56-sloane street , close at , hand , so that [he]249-parkes would be able to keep [his]249-parkes eye continually on the plans . Again , [Irene]186-irene would not be to likely to object to leave [London]2-london if [[[her]186-irene greatest friend]915-her greatest friend 's lover]916-her greatest friend 's lover were given the job . [June]166-june 's marriage might depend on it . [Irene]186-irene could not decently stand in the way of [June]166-june 's marriage ; [she]186-irene would never do that , [he]249-parkes knew [her]186-irene too well . And [June]166-june would be pleased ; of this [he]249-parkes saw the advantage . [Bosinney]168-bosinney looked clever , but [he]168-bosinney had also - and - it was one of [his]168-bosinney great attractions - an air as if [he]168-bosinney did not quite know on which side [his]168-bosinney bread were buttered ; [he]168-bosinney should be easy to deal with in money matters . [Soames]164-soames made this reflection in no defrauding spirit ; it was the natural attitude of [his]168-bosinney mind - of the mind of [any good business man]917-any good business man - of [all those thousands of good business men through whom [he]168-bosinney was threading [his]168-bosinney way up [Ludgate Hill]57-ludgate hill]918-all those thousands of good business men through whom he was threading his way up ludgate hill . Thus [he]168-bosinney fulfilled the inscrutable laws of [his]168-bosinney great class - of human nature itself - when [he]168-bosinney reflected , with a sense of comfort , that [Bosinney]168-bosinney would be easy to deal with in money matters . While [he]168-bosinney elbowed [his]168-bosinney way on , [his]168-bosinney eyes , which [he]168-bosinney usually kept fixed on the ground before [his]168-bosinney feet , were attracted upwards by the dome of [St. Paul 's]58-st. paul 's . It had a peculiar fascination for [him]168-bosinney , that old dome , and not once , but twice or three times a week , would [he]168-bosinney halt in [his]168-bosinney daily pilgrimage to enter beneath and stop in the side aisles for five or ten minutes , scrutinizing the names and epitaphs on [the monuments]919-the monuments . The attraction for [him]168-bosinney of [this great church]920-this great church was inexplicable , unless it enabled [him]168-bosinney to concentrate [his]168-bosinney thoughts on the business of the day . If any affair of particular moment , or demanding peculiar acuteness , was weighing on [his]168-bosinney mind , [he]168-bosinney invariably went in , to wander with mouse - like attention from epitaph to epitaph . Then retiring in the same noiseless way , [he]168-bosinney would hold steadily on up [Cheapside]59-cheapside , a thought more of dogged purpose in [his]168-bosinney gait , as though [he]168-bosinney had seen something which [he]168-bosinney had made up [his]168-bosinney mind to buy . [He]168-bosinney went in this morning , but , instead of stealing from [monument]921-monument to [monument]921-monument , turned [his]168-bosinney eyes upwards to the columns and spacings of the walls , and remained motionless . [Soames]164-soames was solicitor to [this estate]2745-this estate , and [he]164-soames spent nearly an hour in [[the agent]943-the agent 's company]2747-the agent 's company , looking at ground - plans and discussing [the Nicholl]248-the nicholl and other mortgages ; it was as it were by an afterthought that [he]164-soames brought up the question of [the building site]2748-the building site .
